questions.text:
Select the correct option regarding Mobile Medical Units (MMUs).
  1. MMUs are run by the government
  2. MMUs are run by external agencies with medical supplies given by the government.
  3. MMUs are run by the government and medical supplies are also given by the government.
  4. MMUs are run by external agencies and medical supplies are also given by the external agency.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct. MMUs can be run by either Government or an external agency, but the drugs and medical supplies are to be provided always by Government only.

Mobile Medical Units (MMU) is a major initiative under NRHM to provide a range of health care services for people living in remote, inaccessible, un-served, and underserved areas in both rural as well as urban areas, with the aim of taking healthcare services to the doorsteps of such people.

There are 3 models of operationalizing MMUs:

  1. Government operated MMU
  2. Operation of MMU on outsourcing basis by an external agency but capital expenditure, drugs, and supplies provided by Government.
  3. Outsourcing by an external agency which provides both capital expenditure and operational expenditure. However, drugs and supplies are to be provided by Government.

MMUs provide primary care services for common diseases (communicable and non-communicable), RCH services, screening tests, and referral to higher facilities and specialists as required. Clinical services are provided by a Medical Officer and team, and mobilization and outreach services are provided by ANMs and ASHA.

questions.text: The following instrument is used in which of the following surgery?
questions.solution:
The given image is of a Blakesley straight forceps. It is used in functional endoscopic sinus surgery (FESS) operations.

 

Endoscopic surgery is minimally invasive and does not require skin incisions or removal of bone to access the disease. In sinus surgery, this allows ventilation and drainage of the sinuses, preserving nasal and sinus mucosa, and preserving mucociliary clearance. 

Indications of FESS:

  • Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment.
  • Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis.
  • Polypoid rhinosinusitis (diffuse nasal polyposis).
  • Fungal sinusitis with fungal ball or nasal polyp.
  • Antrochoanal polyp.
  • Mucocele of frontoethmoid or sphenoid sinus.
  • Control of epistaxis by endoscopic cautery.
  • Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus.
  • Endoscopic septoplasty.

The below image shows the list of common instruments used during FESS.

questions.text: Which among the following bones is most useful for sex determination?
questions.solution:
The femur is the most useful long bone for sex determination, due to its length and massiveness.

The accuracy of sex determination from bones depends greatly on the age of the subject, the degree of fragmentation, and biological variability. Obvious differences in bones between genders do not become apparent until after puberty. The accuracy of sex determination also depends on whether the total skeleton is available for examination.  

All long bones have a considerable overlap of characteristics between male and female bones. However, there is a significant difference between male and female femurs. For example, the maximum oblique length in the male femur is 459mm but the female femur is only 426mm. 

Pearson and Bell's criteria for sexing of the femur are:

Criteria Male Male or Female Female

Vertical diameter of the femoral head

  >45.5 43.5-41.5 <41.5

Popliteal length

 >145 114-132 <106

Bicondylar width

 >78 74-76 <72

Oblique trochanteric length

 >450 405-430 <390

 

Among these, the most useful criterion is that of the vertical diameter of femoral head.

questions.text: A 48-year-old alcoholic presented to the casualty with fever, productive cough and dyspnea. Chest X-Ray was performed which showed the following finding. Sputum culture was sent which showed lactose fermenting, mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray showing bulging fissure sign are highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumonia.

K. pneumoniae causes lobar pneumonia in alcoholics and diabetics. The patient characteristically presents with fever, dyspnea, and a productive cough with red currant jelly sputum.

Classic chest X-ray findings include:

  • Upper lobe consolidation - classically on the right side.
  • Cavitation
  • Bulging fissure sign - expansive lobar consolidation and inflammatory exudates cause the lower border of the upper lobe to bulge. It can also be seen with space-occupying lesions of the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor. 

The following image shows bulging fissure sign. 

 

Klebsiella pneumoniae ferment lactose and forms mucoid colonies on MacConkey agar. It ferments carbohydrates to produce acid and gas. 

The image below shows a comparison between colonies of E.coli on the left and K. pneumoniae on the right on MacConkey agar.

 

Other infections produced by K. pneumoniae include:

  • Neonatal sepsis
  • Catheter-associated urinary tract infection
  • Pyogenic abscesses
  • Meningitis

questions.text:
Match the following braces to the appropriate clinical scenarios.
  1. A 13-year-old girl with a scoliotic curve beginning at T10
  2. A 12-year-old girl with a single thoracolumbar scoliotic curve to wear while sleeping
  3. A 40-year-old recovering from Dorso-lumbar surgery
  4. A 20-year-old man with a cervical spine injury 
  1. Boston brace
  2. Milwaukee brace
  3. Charleston brace
  4. SOMI brace
  5. ASHE brace

 Abbreviations: ASHE (anterior spinal hyperextension), SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer)
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-A, 2-C, 3-E, 4-D.

A 13-year-old girl with a scoliotic curve beginning at T10 should be provided with a Boston brace. It is the commonest brace prescribed for scoliosis and is a type of thoraco-lumbo-sacral-orthosis (TLSO brace). It has a hard polypropylene outer shell with a soft foam lining inside. The Boston brace works by applying corrective pressure on the convex side of the curve. It is used in patients whose scoliosis curve apex is at T7 or lower. 

Boston brace is also available as a Cervical TLSO brace - which is a TLSO with a neck extension. It is used for the correction of a high thoracic curve.

Wilmington Brace is another common TLSO brace that is custom-fitted based on a cast taken of the patient in the supine position. The brace fits onto the body like a tight jacket, known as a full-contact TLSO. There are no gaps or open spots.

 

A 12-year-old girl with a single thoracolumbar scoliotic curve to wear while sleeping should be provided with a Charleston bending brace. It is the most commonly prescribed nighttime brace. It is custom-fitted based and is intended to be worn while lying down. It applies lateral force to the spine, pushing the curve closer to the midline and holds it in an overcorrected position. 

Providence Brace is similar to the Charleston brace. It applies a hypercorrective force on the spine while lying down. It slightly elevates one shoulder and directly applies lateral and rotational forces on the curve (or both curves if it is a double curve).

 

A 40-year-old recovering from Dorso-lumbar surgery should be provided with an ASHE brace (anterior spinal hyperextension brace).  A hyperextension brace will take the pressure off the weak vertebrae and limit forward bending. 

A 20-year-old man with a cervical spine injury should be treated with a SOMI (Sternal Occipital Mandibular Immobilizer) brace. It is a rigid cervical brace that positions the neck in alignment with the spine and immobilizes it. The SOMI brace may be used as a treatment for cervical spine injury or for cervical pain due to a chronic condition, such as rheumatoid arthritis. It may also be prescribed after cervical spine surgery as a recovery aid.

Other options: 

Milwaukee brace is the originally designed cervico-thoracic-lumbar-sacral orthosis (CTLSO) introduced in the 1940s. It is less commonly used nowadays due to the convenience of modern braces. It is still used for scoliosis with curves in the high thoracic and cervical spine. 

 

Related Pearl: Commonly used splints and their indications

Used in Lower Limbs

Bohler-Braun splint

questions.text: A 48-year-old man is brought due to complaints of hallucinations, abnormal behavior, hydrophobia, and insomnia. He was bitten by a stray dog 4 weeks ago. The patient dies a couple of days later. An autopsy revealed the presence of the following findings in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum. What are these pathognomic microscopic findings called?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of abnormal behavior, hydrophobia, and hallucinations a few weeks after a dog bite is suggestive of rabies. Negri bodies are the pathognomonic microscopic finding in rabies.

Negri bodies are cytoplasmic, round to oval, eosinophilic inclusions that can be found in the pyramidal neurons of the hippocampus and Purkinje cells of the cerebellum, sites that are usually devoid of inflammation.

The rabies virus can be detected within Negri bodies by ultrastructural and immunohistochemical methods.

Image: Characteristic Negri bodies found in the Purkinje cell of the cerebellum.

Clinical stages of rabies:

PHASE TYPICAL DURATION SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS
Incubation period 20-90 Days None
Prodrome 2-10 days Fever, malaise, nausea, vomiting, paresthesia
Acute neurologic disease    
Encephalitic/Furious rabies (80%) 2-7 days Anxiety, Agitation, Hyperactivity, hallucinations, hydrophobia, autonomic dysfunction
Paralytic /dumb rabies (20%) 2-7 days Flaccid paralysis in limbs progressing to quadriparesis with facial paralysis.
Coma 0-10 days Respiratory depression, arrest, death

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

1. Bacterial Inclusion Bodies 

Disease/Bacteria  Inclusion bodies 
Granuloma inguinale, Klebsiella granulomatis Donovan bodies
Psittacosis, Chlamydia psittacci  Levinthal-Cole-Lille bodies (LCL bodies)
Trachoma, Chlamydia trachomatis Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies
Lymphogranuloma venereum, Chlamydia trachomatis Miyagawa’s granulocorpusles
Diphtheria, Corynebacterium diptheriae Babes-Ernst granules

 

2. Viral Inclusion Bodies

  • Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies
Disease/Virus Inclusion bodies
Rabies Negri bodies
Vaccinia, variola (smallpox) Guarnieri bodies
Variola (smallpox) Paschen bodies
Molluscum contagiosum Henderson-Patterson bodies
Fowlpox Bollinger bodies
  • Intra-nuclear Inclusion Bodies 
  Inclusion bodies  Disease/Virus
Cowdry type A Lipschutz inclusions Herpes Virus
Torres bodies Yellow fever

  • Both Intra-nuclear and Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies 
Disease/Virus  Inclusion bodies 
Measles Virus Warthin-Finkedly giant cells

3. Inclusion Bodies in Parasitic Infections

4. Miscellaneous Inclusion Bodies

questions.text: A patient on lithium therapy was started on a drug for hypertension. After few days, he developed coarse tremors and other symptoms suggestive of lithium toxicity. Which of the following anti-hypertensive drug is least likely to be the cause of this toxicity?
questions.solution:
Except for nifedipine, all the other drugs (Enalapril, thiazide, furosemide) causes lithium toxicity.

Lithium toxicity occurs with concomitant use of 

  1. Thiazide diurertics (chlorthalidone)
  2. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (enalapril)
  3. Angiotensin II receptor blocker (telmisartan)
  4. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (indomethacin)
  5. Tetracyclines (doxycycline)
  6. Loop diuretics (furosemide)

These act by increasing the tubular reabsorption of lithium, resulting in decreased excretion of lithium and thereby increasing the serum lithium levels, causing toxicity.

Lithium toxicity: 

Serum lithium level greater than 1.5 mEq/L are considered toxic. Acute intoxication is characterized by vomiting, profuse diarrhea, coarse tremor, ataxia, dysarthria, and convulsions. It may progress to cardiac arrhythmias, coma, and death.

Treatment is supportive which includes dialysis, continuous cardiac monitoring, intubation if needed.

Adverse effects of Lithium:

Central nervous system: Lithium at therapeutic levels cause fine tremors and at toxic levels cause coarse tremors. Incoordination, ataxia, and slurred speech can occur at peak serum concentrations.

Lithium enters into the distal tubular cells in kidney via luminal ENaC. However, it accumulates in the distal tubular cells due to the inability of Na+K+ATPase to secrete lithium via basal membrane. Thereby, lithium inhibits GSK-3ß, leading to vasopressin insensitivity, downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Patients present with polyuria and polydipsia. Amiloride blocks entry of lithium into renal distal tubule ENaCs and is used to treat lithium induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Lithium therapy is associated with hypothyroidism and hypercalcemia related to hyperparathyroidism. Lithium therapy causes significant weight gain.

T wave flattening in ECG occurs in few patients on lithium. At toxic levels, sinus bradycardia, AV block, and cardiac arrhythmias occur. Allergic reactions including dermatitis, folliculitis, and vasculitis can occur with lithium use.

Lithium use in early pregnancy causes Ebstein anomaly in the fetus. Fetal lithium exposure is associated with neonatal goiter, CNS depression, hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), and cardiac murmur.

Due to all these adverse effects, patients on lithium therapy should have routine monitoring of serum electrolytes, serum calcium, thyroid profile, renal function tests, ECG, and serum lithium levels.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text:
The image below shows the effect of various factors on the levels of a hormone. Identify the correct statements regarding the hormone.
  1. It is regulated by GHRH and ghrelin.
  2. Its action on sodium is mediated by IGF-1.
  3. It can be suppressed by the administration of oral glucose.
  4. Its secretion decreases after a protein meal.
  5. Its secretion is increased by ghrelin.
questions.solution:
The hormone depicted in the graph shows pulsatile secretion, with an increase during strenuous exercise and early period of sleep, indicating that it is the growth hormone (GH). The correct statements regarding GH are 1, 3, and 5 (option B).

Growth hormone is secreted from the somatotropes located in the anterior pituitary. Its main role is the growth of the human body.

The levels of growth hormones show diurnal variation as well as variation across different age groups. Adolescents have the highest circulating levels of growth hormone, followed by children and adults. The levels are relatively low during the day and the pulsatile release of this hormone occurs during sleep.

Important regulators of growth hormone:

  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone- stimulates the production of the hormone
  • Somatostatin- inhibits the release of GH
  • Ghrelin- increases the GH release

Stimuli that increase GH secretion:

  • Hypoglycemia, deoxyglucose, fasting
  • Exercise
  • Protein meal, infusion of arginine
  • Glucagon
  • Deep sleep
  • Estrogens and androgens
  • Stressful stimuli

Stimuli that decrease GH secretion:

  • Glucose
  • Cortisol
  • Free fatty acids
  • Growth hormone and IGF-1
  • REM sleep
  • Medroxyprogesterone

GH can act directly on the cells or mediate its actions through insulin-like growth factors (IGF). The functions which are mediated through IGFs are insulin-like activity, anti-lipolytic activity, protein synthesis, and epiphyseal growth. Direct actions of GH are sodium retention, decreased insulin sensitivity, lipolysis, protein synthesis, and epiphyseal growth.

Actions of growth hormone:

  • Growth of cartilage, bones, and organs.
  • Increases amino acid uptake and protein synthesis in the cells and decreases protein breakdown.
  • Diabetogenic action: Increases the hepatic glucose release and decreases the glucose uptake by muscles and fat.
  • Increases fat utilization. It is ketogenic and increases circulating free fatty acid levels.

Since somatostatin inhibits the release of GH, somatostatin analogs like octreotide and lanreotide are used in the treatment of acromegaly.

questions.text: A mother brings her 7-year-old daughter with the complaint that the child wakes up at night screaming, sweating, and terrified. She does not respond to the comforting efforts by her parents. She does not recall the episode in the morning. In which stage of sleep do the episodes experienced by the daughter occur?
questions.solution:
The child who wakes up with intense fear and signs of arousal such as sweating, and does not recall the event in the morning is experiencing sleep terrors or night terrors. Night terrors occur in deep sleep (stages 3 and 4 of NREM sleep).

Sleep terror or night terror is an NREM sleep arousal disorder. In this condition, the patient experiences sudden arousal with intense fearfulness. They may have a piercing scream or cry with manifestations of intense anxiety.

On arousal, they sit up in bed, are unresponsive to stimuli, and are confused and disoriented on awakening. Autonomic disturbances may be present. If vocal, they are incoherent. The patient cannot generally be awakened and efforts to calm them are not successful.  

Sleep terrors only have brief frightening or vivid images, or may not have imagery at all. It can be provoked by sleep deprivation, fever, and central nervous system depressant withdrawal. 

Nightmares have elaborate dream sequences without autonomic disturbances. They occur in REM sleep. The patient can be aroused and typically remembers the dream.

The various stages of sleep and their appearance on EEG are summarized in the image below.

Related Pearl: Events occurring in NREM and REM sleep

Events occurring during NREM stages 3 and 4:

Events

Description

Somnambulism

Sleepwalking

Sleep terror or Night terror

Also called pavor nocturnus.

Awakens with a scream or intense anxiety. Has increased autonomic disturbances.

They do not have a memory of this when they wake up.

Runs in families and seen more frequently in childhood and boys.

Treatment with benzodiazepines is rarely required.

Nocturnal enuresis

Behavioral therapy is the mainstay.

Drugs like desmopressin and imipramine are used.

 

Events occurring in REM sleep:

Events

Description

Nightmares

Fearful sleep without autonomic disturbances that are well remembered in the morning.

TCAs may be used for treatment.

Nocturnal penile tumescence

A normal phenomenon that can be used to differentiate between psychogenic and organic impotence.

Narcolepsy

A disorder of the REM sleep characterized by disturbed sleep in the night, leading to excessive sleep in the morning.

Associated with symptoms such as cataplexy, hypnogogic and hypnopompic hallucination, and sleep paralysis.

 *Hypnogogic hallucinations are those that occur at the start of sleep and hypnopompic hallucinations are those that occur at the end of sleep.

 

Others:

Events

Description

Bruxism (teeth grinding)

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Frontal lobe epilepsy

Occurs in stage 2 NREM sleep.

Sleep talking

Occurs in all stages of sleep and may accompany night terrors and sleepwalking.

Common in children.

No treatment is necessary.

Related Pearl: Stages of Arousal and Sleep

Stage

Behaviour

EEG

Alert wakefulness

Awake, alert with eyes open

Beta rhythm(14-30 Hz)

Relaxed wakefulness

Awake, relaxed with eyes closed
  • Mainly alpha rhythm (8–13 Hz)
  • Changes to the beta rhythm in response to internal or external stimuli.

Relaxed drowsiness
  • Fatigued and tired
  • The head droops, momentary lapses of attention
  • Sleepy but not asleep

Decrease in alpha-wave amplitude and frequency

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)
  • Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks
  • Continuous lack of awareness
  • Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).
  • Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity
  • Vertex waves

NREM 2 (N2) (50-60%)

Further lack of sensitivity to activation and arousal
  • Predominant theta activity (4-7 Hz)
  • K-complex and sleep spindles occur periodically

NREM 3 and 4 (N3) (15-20%)
  • Deep sleep
  • Arousal only with vigorous stimuli
  • Sleep-arousal most difficult

Delta>theta activity

REM (paradoxical) sleep (20-25%)
  • 50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min
  • Dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption
  • EEG resembles that of alert awake state.
  • Saw tooth waves

Note: According to the new classification, stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

Related Pearl: Difference between NREM and REM Sleep

Physiological Process

NREM

REM

Brain activity

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases in motor and sensory areas, while other areas are similar to NREM

Heart rate

Slows from wakefulness

Increases and varies compared to NREM

Blood pressure

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases (up to 30 percent) and varies from NREM

Sympathetic nerve activity

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases significantly from wakefulness

Muscle tone

Similar to wakefulness

Absent

Blood flow to brain

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases from NREM, depending on brain region

Respiration

Decreases from wakefulness

Increases and  varies from NREM, but may show brief stoppages; coughing suppressed

Airway resistance

Increases from wakefulness

Increases and  varies from wakefulness

Body temperature

Is regulated at lower set point than wakefulness; shivering initiated at lower temperature than during wakefulness

Is not regulated; no shivering or sweating; temperature drifts toward that of the local environment

Sexual arousal

Occurs infrequently

Greater than NREM

questions.text: A patient is undergoing Doppler ultrasonographic assessment for varicose veins. When the probe was placed inferior to the inguinal crease, the sign shown in the below image was seen on the transverse view in the B-mode. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
The sign in the image given above is the Mickey mouse sign, which represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels.

The Mickey mouse sign is seen on the transverse B-mode of USG.

It includes 

  • Great saphenous vein (GSV),
  • Common femoral vein (CFV), and
  • Common femoral artery (CFA)

Normally, the GSV and CFV lie medial to the common femoral artery, which gives rise to the sign.

Mickey mouse in medicine:

  • Mickey mouse appearance - seen on antenatal ultrasound, due to absent cranial bone/brain and bulging orbits in anencephaly
  • Mickey mouse appearance - seen on MRI in progressive supranuclear palsy
  • The Mickey Mouse sign also represents the configuration of the portal triad - the portal vein, common bile duct, and the hepatic artery on biliary ultrasound.

questions.text: During a preoperative anesthetic evaluation, pharmacologic stress echocardiography is being undertaken for a patient with chronic pulmonary disease. Which of the following agents can be used for inducing pharmacological stress in this patient?
questions.solution:
Dobutamine can be used for the induction of pharmacological stress in a patient with chronic pulmonary disease.

Dobutamine is a potent β-receptor agonist used for stress testing. It increases myocardial oxygen demand by increasing contractility, heart rate, and blood pressure in a similar manner as exercise. Dobutamine stress testing is the preferred choice for the assessment of myocardial viability and is generally used as an alternative to vasodilator stress in patients with chronic pulmonary disease, where vasodilators are contraindicated.  

Cardiac stress testing is performed in patients with known or suspected coronary artery disease. It is also done for preoperative CVS monitoring in a patient with risk factors for myocardial infarction. Generally, exercise stress testing is preferred because it provides information on functional capacity, exercise tolerance, and symptom provocation. However, some patients undergo pharmacologic stress testing. Indications for pharmacologic stress testing include: 

  • Unstable angina
  • Inability to exercise
  • History of uncontrolled heart failure at risk for deterioration
  • Poorly controlled blood pressure
  • History of aortic stenosis
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Acute pulmonary embolism
  • Acute pericarditis or myocarditis
  • Severe pulmonary hypertension
  • Chronic pulmonary disease

Vasodilators are the most commonly used pharmacologic stressors for myocardial perfusion imaging. Vasodilator stress acts by increasing and diverting blood flow to the non-diseased blood vessels so that the diseased vessels can be visualized clearly. It is brought about by drugs such as adenosine, dipyridamole, and regadenoson.

Contraindications to vasodilator stress testing are:

  • Pronounced active bronchospastic airway disease
  • Significant hypotension

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient has been brought to the hospital following blunt trauma to the chest and abdomen. On examination, it was found that the structures passing through the most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening situated at the level of the T12 vertebra have been injured. All of the following structures are injured in this case except?
questions.solution:
The most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening situated at the level of the T12 vertebra is the aortic opening. The right vagus nerve is not injured in the given case as it passes through the oesophageal opening while all these other structures are injured.

The diaphragm has several openings through which structures can pass between the thorax and abdomen. There are three large openings and several smaller openings. The large openings are the aortic hiatus, the oesophagal hiatus, and the caval hiatus.

The aortic opening is the most posteroinferior large diaphragmatic opening. It is found at the level of the lower border of the twelfth thoracic vertebra and the corresponding intervertebral disc. It is bounded by the diaphragmatic crura laterally, the vertebral column posteriorly, and the median arcuate ligament anteriorly. 

Structures passing through the aortic opening are,

  • Aorta
  • Thoracic duct
  • Azygous vein
  • Hemiazygous vein

Related Pearl: Diaphragmatic openings

Major openings through the diaphragm

Level of opening

T8

T10

T12

Located in

In the central tendon

In the muscular part

In crus of the diaphragm

Structures passing through

 

Inferior Vena cava

Right phrenic nerve 

Oesophagus

Vagus nerve- right and left

Aorta

Thoracic duct

Azygous vein

Hemiazygous vein

 

Minor openings through the diaphragm

  • Space of Larry (Costo-Xiphoid gap) - Superior epigastric artery
  • Medial arcuate ligament - Sympathetic chain
  • Lateral arcuate ligament - Subcostal nerves and vessels

 

Note:

Splanchnic nerves pass through the right and left crus of the diaphragm.

The azygous vein may sometimes pass through the right crus of the diaphragm.

The hemizygous vein may sometimes pass through the left crus of the diaphragm.

questions.text: A patient was advised to take green leafy vegetables as a natural dietary source of vitamin K. Which is the compound that acts as the source of vitamin K in these vegetables?
questions.solution:
The normal dietary source of vitamin K is phylloquinone or vitamin K1, found in green leafy vegetables.

Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin and its deficiency leads to bleeding disorders.

Three compounds have the biological activity of vitamin K:

  • Phylloquinone (Vitamin K1) is the normal dietary source of Vitamin K that is found in green leafy vegetables.
  • Menaquinone (Vitamin K2) is synthesized by intestinal bacteria.
  • Menadione (Vitamin K3) and menadiol diacetate are synthetic compounds that are metabolized to phylloquinone.

Phyloquinone

Elevated prothrombin time and bleeding

Haemorrhagic disease of newborn

Hemolysis

Hyperbilirubinemia

Kernicterus

<1 year - 2-3 µg

Children - 30-50 µg

 		 55 µg  55 µg 

Note:The RDA for Vitamin D in the elderly (>60 years) is 800 IU.

questions.text: An asymptomatic 30-year-old man presents with a lesion on his thigh as seen in the below image. He returned a week ago from the US where he inspected farming areas during the summer. The best management for this patient would be:

choices.text: Reassurance as it is a fixed drug eruption

questions.solution:
The given image classically depicts the bull’s eye lesion (erythema chronicum migrans) and the clinical history is suggestive of the diagnosis of Lyme disease. The drug of choice for early asymptomatic Lyme disease is Doxycycline 100 mg BD.

Lyme disease is caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted by the hard tick, Ixodes. It usually occurs after a tick bite while strolling through the farms. Most of them do not recall the bite and the initial presentation is only a skin lesion known as erythema chronicum migrans.

It is only after dissemination, that the disease spreads to joints (arthritis), heart (AV blocks), and the nervous system (neuroborreliosis).

The treatment protocol for early Lyme disease includes:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg BD (Drug of choice) for 2-3 weeks (or)
  • Amoxicillin 500 – 1000 mg for 2-3 weeks (for children < 9 years, pregnant women)

In severe disseminated cases, Ceftriaxone 2 g IV for 2-3 weeks can be given. 

Other options:

Option A - Chloroquine and tafenoquine are used to prevent Plasmodium vivax malaria relapse. There are no clinical symptoms suggestive of Malaria. 

Option C - Antihistamines can be used to treat urticaria. Patients present with short-lived itchy weals, angioedema, or both. 

Option D - Fixed drug eruption presents as a sharply defined oval or round erythematous, edematous plaque. It becomes dusky, violaceous, and vesicular or bullous. It occurs in the lips, genitals, palms, and soles.

questions.text:
Match the syndromes given in column A with the structures involved given in column B. (CN- cranial nerve, CST- corticospinal tract)
Column A Column B
1. Weber syndrome A. CST, medial lemniscus, hypoglossal nerve
2. Medial medullary syndrome B. CN III, ventral midbrain, CST, red nucleus
3. Millard–Gubler syndrome C. CN VIII, CN IX and CST
4. Benedikt syndrome D. CN III, ventral midbrain, CST
  E. CN VI, CN VII, ventral pons
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-A, 3-E, 4-B.

Important syndromes in the brainstem are

Midbrain

  • Weber syndrome- It affects cranial nerve (CN) III, ventral midbrain, and corticospinal tract. Patients will have contralateral hemiplegia and paralysis of the third cranial nerve.
  • Benedikt syndrome- It affects CN III, ventral midbrain, corticospinal tract, and red nucleus. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, third nerve palsy, intention tremor, and cerebellar ataxia.
  • Top of basilar syndrome- It affects occipital lobes, midbrain oculomotor nuclei, cerebral peduncle, medial and temporal lobe, and thalamus. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, cortical blindness, oculomotor deficits, memory difficulty, and contralateral sensory deficit.

Pons

  • Milard Gubler syndrome- It affects CN VI, CN VII, and ventral pons. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, CN VI and CN VII palsies.
  • Clumsy hand syndrome- It affects the corticospinal tract. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, dysarthria, and facial weakness.
  • Foville syndrome- It affects CN VII, ventral pons, and paramedian pontine reticular formation. Patients will have ipsilateral CN VII palsy, contralateral hemiparesis, gaze palsy to the side of the lesion.

Medulla

  • Medial medullary syndrome- It affects the corticospinal tract, medial lemniscus, and hypoglossal nerve. Patients will have contralateral hemiparesis, loss of position and vibratory sensation, and ipsilateral tongue paresis. 
  • Lateral medullary syndrome- It affects the spinothalamic tract, trigeminal nucleus, cerebellum and inferior cerebellar peduncle, vestibular nuclei, and nucleus ambiguus. Patients will have ataxia, dysphagia, hemisensory loss, facial weakness, and Horner syndrome.

Brown Sequard syndrome is the hemisection of the spinal cord. Patients present with ipsilateral weakness, ipsilateral loss of position sense, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Weber's syndrome

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient with no significant past history comes to the emergency department with sudden onset of palpitations. On examination, her pulse is 140 bpm and her blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg. Her ECG is given below. What will be the initial line of management?
questions.solution:
The ECG is suggestive of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT) as it shows narrow QRS complexes without visible p waves and pseudo R' waves in aVR lead. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, a carotid sinus massage will be provided as first-line therapy.

Vagal maneuvers like the carotid sinus massage and the Valsalva maneuver are techniques used to increase vagal parasympathetic tone.

Vagal maneuvers transiently increase the arterial pressure in the carotid sinuses and aortic arch. This triggers the baroreceptor reflex, which increases parasympathetic output to the heart via cranial nerve X. 

The right vagus nerve innervates the sinoatrial (SA) node and the left vagus nerve innervates the atrioventricular (AV) node. Stimulation of the right and left vagus nerve cause slowing of the electrical activity within the SA node and AV node.

Thus, vagal stimulation results in a decrease in the speed and frequency of electrical impulses in the heart, which could ultimately slow or terminate a tachydysrhythmia.

Treatment of PSVT:

In hemodynamically unstable patients, QRS-synchronous DC cardioversion should be done.

In hemodynamically stable patients,

  1. Vagal maneuvers such as carotid sinus massage are provided as first-line therapy only if there is a low risk of carotid vascular disease. It is contraindicated in patients with carotid bruit and prior history of stroke.
  2. If the vagal maneuvers fail or cannot be performed, intravenous adenosine can be used.
  3. If adenosine does not work, IV beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem) can be used
  4. Irregular, wide complex tachycardia can be treated with IV procainamide, ibutilide, or cardioversion. 

Care should be taken to perform continuous ECG monitoring with facilities for emergency cardioversion and defibrillation on standby.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presented with complaints of pain, photophobia, and redness in the eye following injury by vegetative matter. On examination, appearance is as shown in the below-given image. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Signs are more pronounced than symptoms
Wessely’s immune ring is a feature
It can occur in immunocompromised patients

questions.solution:
This patient with history of ocular injury due to vegetative matter with ocular pain, redness, and the image depicting a corneal ulcer with feathery margins and a hypopyon is likely to have a fungal corneal ulcer. In this condition, the hypopyon is not sterile. 

Fungal or mycotic keratitis is seen in tropical countries, rural areas, and in individuals who are immunocompromised. It occurs due to inoculation with Aspergillus, Fusarium, or Candida species. It is generally seen after ocular injury with vegetable matter. 

The signs of a fungal corneal ulcer are generally more pronounced than the symptoms. Signs include: 

  • Dry slough with feathery borders
  • Thick, immobile, hypopyon that occurs due to direct invasion of anterior chamber by fungal hyphae in thick exudates
  • Wesseley's immune ring due to deposition of immune complexes and inflammatory cells around the ulcer
  • Satellite lesions
  • Ciliary and conjunctival congestion (symptoms of pain, watering, and photophobia are less severe than in cases of bacterial corneal ulcers)

Fungal corneal ulcers are treated topically with natamycin, voriconazole, nystatin, or amphotericin B drops. If the ulcers are severe with hypopyon, perforated, or if there is endophthalmitis, then systemic antifungals need to be provided. Examples include oral ketoconazole or voriconazole. Surgical management is indicated if the ulcer progresses despite medical therapy.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in proper order of blood supply to the uterus.

1 - Arcuate artery
2 - Basal artery
3 - Radial artery
4 - Spiral artery
5 - Uterine artery
questions.solution:
The correct order of the blood supply of the uterus is 5-1-3-2-4

The blood supply of the uterus is as follows:

Uterine artery (5) -> Arcuate artery (1) -> Radial artery (3) -> Basal artery (2) (Supplies basal layer of endometrium ) -> Spiral artery (4) (Supplies functional endometrium)

Bleeding during normal menstruation is due to the rupture of the spiral artery.

During normal menstruation:

Superficial layer (2/3) Deep layer (1/3) 
Consists of stratum compactum and stratum spongiosum Consists of stratum basalis
Supplied by spiral artery Supplied by basilar arteries
During the secretory phase, the artery undergoes vasoconstriction due to PGF-2alpha. Cannot undergo vasoconstriction as the artery is straight
Shed during menses (Normal shedding and bleeding) Shed in the absence of progesterone (Heavy bleeding)

questions.text:
A newborn is being evaluated for yellowish discoloration of the sclera and elevated bilirubin levels. Which of the following are indications to further evaluate the child to identify the cause of jaundice?
  1. Serum bilirubin of 16 mg/dL in a full-term infant 
  2. Jaundice appearing on the first day of birth
  3. Jaundice persisting after 14 days
  4. Direct bilirubin fraction < 2mg/dL on the 3rd day
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 2, and 3 are suggestive of a pathological cause of jaundice and need to be further evaluated for the cause of jaundice. 

Physiological jaundice occurs due to increased bilirubin production due to the destruction of the fetal RBCs along with a transient limitation in bilirubin conjugation in the immature neonatal liver. It first appears on the 2nd or 3rd day, usually peaks between 2nd and 4th day at 5–6 mg/dL, and decreases to <2 mg/dL between the 5th and 7th days after birth.

Risk factors for physiological jaundice include maternal age, maternal diabetes, prematurity, drugs(Vitamin K3, novobiocin), polycythemia, male sex, trisomy 21, cutaneous bruising, blood extravasation as in cephalhematoma, breastfeeding, weight loss, and a family history of physiological jaundice.

Jaundice in the newborn is not always physiological and in some cases, there can be an underlying pathology. Given below are the indications to evaluate a newborn to identify the cause of pathological jaundice:

  • Jaundice that appears in the first 24-36 hours of birth
  • A rise in serum bilirubin faster than 5mg/dL/24hr
  • Serum bilirubin > 12mg/dL in a full-term infant(especially if there are no risk factors)
  • Serum bilirubin > 10-14mg/dL in a preterm infant
  • Persistent jaundice after 10-14 days of birth
  • Direct bilirubin > 2mg/dL at any time

Other features suggestive of a nonphysiological cause of jaundice are a positive family history of any hemolytic disease, pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, vomiting, lethargy, poor feeding, apnea, bradycardia, hypothermia, light-colored stools, failure of phototherapy to lower the bilirubin levels, and signs of kernicterus.

If there is persistent indirect hyperbilirubinemia for more than 2 weeks it indicates hemolysis, hereditary glucuronyl transferase deficiency, breastmilk jaundice, hypothyroidism, or intestinal obstruction.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements regarding Hashimoto's thyroiditis:
  1. It most commonly causes hyperthyroidism.
  2. Antibodies against thyroid peroxidase are seen. 
  3. Thyroid profile shows low TSH and high T4.
  4. It is associated with thyroid lymphomas.

TSH - Thyroid-stimulating hormone

T4 - Thyroxine
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 4 are correct regarding Hashimoto's thyroiditis. It is characterized by the presence of antibodies against thyroid peroxidase and is associated with thyroid lymphomas.

Statements 1 and 3 are false. Hashimoto's thyroiditis, most commonly causing hypothyroidism (not hyperthyroidism), is associated with high TSH and low T4 levels (not low TSH and high T4). 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure.

It occurs most commonly among middle-aged women. It is associated with malignant lymphoma of thyroid.

Patients present with painless diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland. Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism. However, initially few patients may present with a transient hyperthyroid state, known as hashitoxicosis, due to the release of thyroid hormones by disruption of the thyroid follicles.

Laboratory investigations:

  • T3 and T4 are low
  • TSH is raised
  • Presence of autoantibodies against:
    • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
    • Thyroglobulin

Histopathology of Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Microscopic features include:

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centres.
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles, lined by epithelial cells, contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. These epithelial cells are referred to as Hurthle cells.

Hürthle cells arise from the follicular epithelium. These oncocytic cells include an eosinophilic granular cytoplasm.

The following image shows a histopathological picture of Hashimoto thyroiditis :

 

Note:

  • Low TSH and high T4 levels can be seen in hyperthyroidism. Causes of hyperthyroidism includes Grave's disease, toxic goitre, and toxic adenoma.
  • Low TSH and normal T4 levels are seen in subclinical hyperthyroidism.
  • High TSH and normal T4 levels are seen in subclinical hypothyroidism.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

 

Primary

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

Secondary

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

Tertiary

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

RAI therapy for Grave’s disease

Post thyroidectomy

Excessive iodine intake - Wolff Chiakoff effect

Subacute thyroiditis

Medications: Antithyroid drugs, lithium

Iodine deficiency, dyshormonogenesis

Pituitary tumour

Pituitary resection or ablation

Hypothalamic insufficiency

Resistance to thyroid hormone
